column169: Terrestrial animal  isolates linked to animal disease. ,Zoonotic pathogenic bacteria (e.g. Salmonella spp. in terrestrial animals) ,Commensal isolates (e.g. E. coli for terrestrial animals) ,Specific resistance phenotypes (e.g. ESBL producing indicator E. coli obtained from healthy animals in key food producing species). Please specify : AMR monitoring in terrestrial animals is carried out in accordance with Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2020/1729 of 17 November 2020 on the monitoring and reporting of antimicrobial resistance in zoonotic and commensal bacteria and repealing Implementing Decision 2013/652/EU. In  accordance  with  Decision 2020/1729/EU,  EU MSs should report on AMR in Salmonella spp., C. jejuni and C. coli, indicator commensal E. coli, and on extended-spectrum beta-lactamase  (ESBL)-, AmpC- or carbapenemase-producing Salmonella spp. and E.  coli. Randomised, representative sampling is performed at the level of the major food-producing animal production categories, such as broilers, laying hens, fattening pigs, fattening turkeys and bovine animals under 1 year of age (calves). Isolates linked to animal disease should be tested as an evidence of treatment of food producing animals with critically important antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, 3-4th generation cephalosporines and colistin), in accordance with national law.

column248: The Ministry of Health, through the secretariat of the Multisectoral Coordinating Committee (MCC), facilitates the release of funds and proposal development for partner support. The secretariat has led the development of several key guidelines and policies on antimicrobial resistance (AMR), including:  Integrated AMR Surveillance Guidelines (2021)  Antimicrobial Stewardship Guidelines (2021)  One Health Training Module and AMR Research Agenda  Integration of the WHO AWaRe classification into the Essential Medicines List  AMR reporting tools for various levels of care, such as:  Antimicrobial Use and Surveillance Register  AMR Awareness Attendance Sheet and Logbook  Reserved Antibiotics Pre-Authorization Register  Antibiogram and Drug-Bug Chart  Supervisory Checklists  Despite the availability of these guiding documents, implementation remains a major challenge. Efforts to operationalize them are hindered by limited resources, particularly for conducting visits to district-level facilities across the human, animal, and environmental health sectors.

column248: With regards to 6.2: Luxembourg is currently analysing samples from waste water treatment plants in feasibility studies for a 4th treatment step in order to eliminate micropollutants. Certain antimicrobial residues are also included in these studies. In the context of the watch list surveillance (implemented by the priority substances directive 2008/105 and 2013/39/EU) Luxembourg regularly carries out surveillance on some antimicrobials in surface waters. The list of substances is regularly updated by decisions of the European Commission (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/en/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32025D0439). Several other non-regular surveillance campaigns also include antimicrobials.  While Luxembourg has no legislation yet (6.3+6.4) specific to the discharge/presence of antimicrobial substances in water (waste water and surface waters), all discharges into surface waters or discharges from non-household sources into sewage systems are subject to discharge permits (loi modifiée du 19 décembre 2008 relative à l’eau, the national transposition of the water frame work directive (2000/60/CE). If a discharge for example from a manufacturing plant is expected to include these substances, the discharge permit will address this with emission limit values or other restrictions. This is in accordance with article 10 (combined approach) of the water framework directive. The discharge permits for all health care facilities (hospitals, care homes, etc.) in Luxembourg impose a double sewage system that allows a future treatment of wastewater charge with pharmaceutical residues (including but not limited to antimicrobials).     In October 2022 the European Commission published proposals for the recasts of the urban waste water treatment directive (91/271) as well as the priority substances directive  (2008/105 resp. 2013/39). In November 2024 the new urban waste water treatment directive was published (2024/3019) and requires a quaternary treatment step for waste water treatment plants above 150 000 p.e. (one of the indicators of this elimination is clarithromycin) as well as monitoring of antimicrobial resistance in waste water. The directive also includes timelines for these obligations. Luxembourg is currently in the process of transposing the directive into Luxembourgish legislation. The directive on priority substances is still in negotiations at the EU level but when passed in its current form will impose monitoring as well as environmental quality standards for some antibiotics in surface waters. These obligations will however only come into effect 2 years after they have been voted on by the European Parliament. (so at the earliest end of 2027).  With regards to 6.6: national information campaigns regularly remind the public that toilets and sinks are not rubbish bins (“la toilette et l’évier ne sont pas des poubelles”) and that surplus of unused antibiotics should be brought back to the pharmacies or specialised waste collecting centres.

column81: A)	Pesticides used on plant protection: Only active substances included in Annex I of Regulation 1107/2009 (apart from exceptional authorisations according to article 53) can be used in Plant protection products (PPP). The competent authority is the Ministry of Agriculture. The Ministry publishes in its web page a list of authorized active substances.  All products used in Spain must be registered in the Official Registry of Products and Materials for Plant protection, managed by the Ministry of Agriculture. Previous registration, the use is evaluated according European harmonized framework considering risk identificantion and mitigation for the intended crop. The procedure is regulated by twoRoyal Decrees: “Real Decreto 971/2014, de 21 de noviembre, por el que se regula el procedimiento de evaluación de productos fitosanitarios” and “Real Decreto 1311/2012, de 14 de septiembre, por el que se establece el marco de actuación para conseguir un uso sostenible de los productos fitosanitarios” Other National laws apply on the subject like the National law on plant health: “Ley 43/2002, de 20 de noviembre, de sanidad vegetal”   Links (content in Spanish):  https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/agricultura/temas/sanidad-vegetal/ https://sede.mapa.gob.es/portal/site/seMAPA/ficha-procedimiento?procedure_suborg_responsable=93&procedure_etiqueta_pdu=null&procedure_id=404   B)	Biocides These are pesticides used in farms and other relevant áreas to maintain hygiene or control pests which are relevant in the AMR.   General link with relevant information on several aspects:  Ministerio de Sanidad - Ciudadanos - Productos Biocidas  European legislation is applied in Spain (Regulation 528/2012 on marketing and use). National legislation also applies: More details on regulation framework in Spain in this link:  Ministerio de Sanidad - Ciudadanos - Productos Biocidas   The competent authorities are specified here: Ministerio de Sanidad - Ciudadanos - Productos Biocidas   The competent authorities are the Ministry of Health that coordinates and manages the registry and the Ministry on Ecologic Transition and Demographic Challenge (Environment) being other Ministries assigned on determined tasks: Ministry of Agriculture to determine the efficacy of types of biocides (PT) 3, 18, 19 and the Spanish Agency of Medicines and Medical Devices for PT1 and PT 2 and PT 19. The case of antiseptic products applied to human skin previous to surgery or injection are considered as human medicines.  There is a registry of products and substances here: http://www.mscbs.es/ciudadanos/saludAmbLaboral/prodQuimicos/sustPreparatorias/docs_biocidas/registros.htm  Missing here a section regarding the monitoring and control of manure and sludge from STPs to be used as fertilizer. Those are AMR vectors.

(Antibiotics are not approved as active substances in the EU, except for a few cases where MS authorise antibiotics under the so-called Emergency Authorisation procedure foreseen in Article 53 of Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 to combat pests for which no other means are available. The EU Commission requests member states on an annual basis to notify antibiotics they have authorised during the last year for Emergency Authorisation. That information is collected in a report that is then made available to all Member States).

column183: Whilst there are no specific antimicrobial resistance (AMR) training courses, the FSA food safety guidance, advice and training are designed to reduced microbiological hazards in food including bacteria that that may be AMR. In the UK, food handlers don’t have to hold a food hygiene certificate to prepare or sell food but Food Business Operators (FBOs) must ensure that food handlers receive the appropriate supervision and training in food hygiene. This must be in-line with the area staff work in and to enable them to handle food safely. We have online ‘Safer Food, Better Business’ (SFBB) information packs for businesses covering numerous sectors such as caterers, retailers, childminders, Chinese and Indian Cuisine, residential care homes and teaching resources for colleges. These have been designed to improve good personal hygiene’s through fact sheets covering the FSA 4C’s principles (avoiding cross-contamination, chilling, cleaning and cooking), management and using the diary. These practical and easy-to-use packs help FBOs to comply with food hygiene regulations, show what you do to make food safely, train staff, protect business’s reputation, improve your business and food hygiene rating score
